description.narrative: To support Linking and Learning Facilitation activities, HJA and Phan-Thin will use the “FAH” approach the key approach to facilitate learning journey of grantees relate to transition of “Storytelling to story doer/action”. The mechanism and tools in learning aredesigned to be fit with grantees capacity individually. “FAH” Approach definition is “F” means facilitation based on blending of coaching and mentoring approach to assure the continuity of learning and self-development of grantees. “A” means action along the learning journey of grantees that demonstrate via the linking and learning activities that bring in explore, experiment and exchange (3E) concept. “H” means harvesting of the lesson learnt from explore, experiment and exchange along the learning journey. Effective harvesting comes from effective coordination, collaboration, caring, networking, nurture and neutral. Harvesting will focus to the growth beyond the technical aspects. HJA and Phan-Thin will develop the guidebook and toolbox as the key strategy for linking and learning facilitation that gathering entire principles, process, and tools to support everyone involving with this project. The guidebook and toolbox produce in hard copy and upload to the website, grantees will get 1 set and can download for soft copy if need. The improvement of guidebook and toolbox will be during the project’s life on monthly basis. From above approach, HJA and Phan-Thin identifythe position named “FAH” and “Learning <(><<)>(><(>&<)><(><<)>)> Observation Team (LO)” to supportthe linking and learning facilitation. “FAH” will support “LO” and NPAs in specific areas of learning such as shaping the knowledge by transition lesson learnt to action, scaling up the lesson learnt, etc., in participatory approach. “LO” will collaborateclosely with NPAs as the learner and observer act as the catalyst for learning of NPAs base on explore, experiment and exchange (3E) concept, point out the learning points and changes that can benefit to NPAs, along their journey. “LO” will flag “FAH” forsupport in case of any interesting topics that NPAsand “LO” find out together. “LO” will be also the role model that represents and inspiration the grantees on being a good learner and peer to peer learning. NPAs and “LO” will capture the lesson learntand identify the credible evidence, bring to exchange in linking and learning event and forum, CoP, CoS, social event, etc., in country, regional, and global. Additionally, “FAH” will deliver support to the “LO” by using “Peer coaching” to cope with anyissues during “LO” collaboration with grantees. The entire lesson learnt from linking and learning activities presented through publication and multimedia platforms such as social media, online and offline. Moreover, the findings of any tools (learning and/or working) will upload to the “Initiative toolbox” in cloud system by grantees,FAH participate in shaping into effective tools, grantees can explore any tools in “initiative toolbox”, tools experiments and exchange the results in organization level,withother NPAs, and network level, respectively. The monitoring and evaluation of learning will support by “FAH” to make sure that the linking and learning activities are on track and can capture the significant changes during the learning journey of grantees. HJA and Phan-Thin will design the M<(><<)>(><(>&<)><(><<)>)>E system since the beginning, to make sure effective tools and methods are in place.

participating-org.narrative:
Huam Jai Asasamak Association (“United in Volunteering”, or HJA) is a Lao Civil Society Organization, formed following a research project commissioned by the Canadian organization CUSO in 2003. In 2007 HJA established the Lao PDR’s first national youth volunteering programme, focusing on volunteers from rural areas and ethnic minorities aged between 18 and 25 years old. The programme providesopportunity to work as volunteer for twelve months with partner organization in community development, and so they gain knowledge, skills and experience in strengthening their community’s growth and development. To date, over 100 young people have successfully completed this volunteer internship programme. In 2012 HJA then puts in community volunteering programme, support volunteers who havecompleted their placements to develop projects within their communities and others in term of building capacity of marginalized group, particularly ethnic minority, and women—over past ten years, has supported over 100 volunteers working with 30 partners in the Lao PDR and has improved the lives of over 1,000 people living in disadvantaged communities. Since 2014 HJA is registered as Non-Profit Association with the Lao Ministry of Home Affairs. Under HJA’s strategy plan 2017 - 2020, HJA has goal to develop youth to be leader, facilitator, and contribution to community development as well as to build capacity, vision, and mission to achievement and acknowledgement in public under title: “HuamJai Assamak has standard administration, Services and Central capacity building of Youth” and being representative for youth’s rights protection, promotion, and fulfil for all youth in community.
Phan-Thin Social Enterprise is a none profit Organization. It works on community development toward to liveable society where there is justice, wellbeing, and prosperity for all people. Phan-Thin is focusing on contributing to eradication of all form of inequality and injustice in Lao society by developing the capacity and enhancing a participatory framework for disadvantage and minority people and develop the capacity of youth in all CSOs so they will engage in Social, Environment, Economic Development (SEED) by using holistic and interaction approach.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation

description.narrative: Civil society actors transformed and strengthened,
CSO actors that build trust and work in inclusive way in coalitions
CSO that improved their acccess to flexible resources to actively address, reclaim and navigate civic space offline and online, involving and considering esp. marginalized groups
CSOs that strengthened the links with their constituencies due to changed ways of working
CSOs with improved risk strategies and improves support when a civic space crisis occurs
CSOs with increased women and youth in leadership positions
informal movements/individuals with access to flexible resources to address, reclaim and navigate civic space offline and/or online
